description: Learn to capture user input using HTML forms, inputs, and buttons.

slides.title: Introduction to Forms
slides.content:
# HTML Forms üìù

Forms are used to collect user input. Whether it's a login screen, a search bar, or a feedback box, it's all HTML forms!

## The <form> Element

The `<form>` element defines a form to collect user input.

```html
<form action="/submit_data" method="post">
  <!-- Inputs go here -->
</form>
```

- `action`: Where to send the form data
- `method`: How to send tags (usually `GET` or `POST`)

slides.title: Input Types part 1
slides.content:
# Common Inputs ‚å®Ô∏è

The `<input>` element is the most used form element. It can verify depending on the `type` attribute.

## Text & Password

```html
<!-- Single line text -->
<label>Username: <input type="text"></label>

<!-- Masked characters -->
<label>Password: <input type="password"></label>
```

## Radio & Checkbox

```html
<!-- Radio: Select ONE option -->
<input type="radio" name="gender" value="male"> Male
<input type="radio" name="gender" value="female"> Female

<!-- Checkbox: Select MULTIPLE options -->
<input type="checkbox" name="vehicle" value="bike"> Bike
<input type="checkbox" name="vehicle" value="car"> Car
```

slides.title: Buttons and Submission
slides.content:
# Buttons üîò

You can create buttons using `<button>` or `<input type="button">`.

## Button Types

```html
<!-- Submits the form data -->
<button type="submit">Register</button>

<!-- Resets form inputs -->
<button type="reset">Clear</button>

<!-- Generic button (needs JS) -->
<button type="button">Click Me</button>
```

## The Label Element

Notice we used `<label>` earlier? It's important for usability and accessibility.

```html
<!-- Associates text with input -->
<label for="email">Email:</label>
<input type="email" id="email" name="email">
```

> üéØ **Tip:** Clicking a label automatically focuses its associated input!

slides.title: Form Validation
slides.content:
# Basic Validation ‚úÖ

HTML5 provides built-in validation without needing JavaScript!

## Required Fields

Add the `required` attribute to make a field mandatory.

```html
<input type="text" required>
```

## Specific Types

Browser checks for valid formats specifically:

```html
<input type="email"> <!-- Must contain @ -->
<input type="url">   <!-- Must start with http:// -->
<input type="number" min="1" max="10">
```

## Placeholders

text displayed inside the input field before typing:

```html
<input type="text" placeholder="Enter your name...">
```

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Form Mastery üéì

- ‚úÖ **`<form>`** wraps your input elements
- ‚úÖ **`<input>`** is versatile (`text`, `password`, `radio`, `checkbox`)
- ‚úÖ **`<button>`** handles submission
- ‚úÖ **`<label>`** improves accessibility
- ‚úÖ **Attributes** like `required` and `placeholder` enhance UX
